title: SMRTer Chatbots: Improving Non-Task-Oriented Dialog with Simulated Multi-Reference Training
summary: Simulated Multiple Reference Training is comparable to pretraining in human evaluation quality, and outperforms pretraining on automatic quality and lexical diversity, without requiring related-domain dialog data.
venue: Findings

title: The circle of meaning: from translation to paraphrasing and back
summary: It is claimed that the sentential paraphraser, once built in this fashion, can provide a solution to the reference sparsity problem and, hence, be used to improve the performance a bilingual SMT system.

title: Examining Linguistic Characteristics of Paraphrase in Test-Taker Summaries. Research Report. ETS RR-12-18.
authors: J. Burstein,Michael Flor,J. Tetreault,Nitin Madnani,Steven Holtzman

title: Transliteration normalization for Information Extraction and Machine Translation
summary: This work aims to identify and cluster name spelling variants using a Statistical Machine Translation method: word alignment, which results in tens of thousands of high-precision name transliteration spelling variants being extracted from sentence-aligned bilingual corpora in Arabic and English.
venue: Journal of King Saud University: Computer and Information Sciences

title: Automatic Machine Translation Evaluation in Many Languages via Zero-Shot Paraphrasing
summary: This work proposes the use of a sequence-to-sequence paraphraser for automatic machine translation evaluation, and finds that the model conditioned on the source instead of the reference outperforms every quality estimation as a metric system from the WMT19 shared task on quality estimation by a statistically significant margin in every language pair.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Explicit Representation of the Translation Space: Automatic Paraphrasing for Machine Translation Evaluation
summary: This work assesses the feasibility of improving BLEU using state-of-the-art neural paraphrasing techniques to generate additional references and explores the extent to which diverse paraphrases can adequately cover the space of valid translations and an alternative approach of generating paraphrase constrained by MT outputs.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Rachel Bawden,Biao Zhang,Lisa Yankovskaya,Andre Tattar,Matt Post

title: A Study in Improving BLEU Reference Coverage with Diverse Automatic Paraphrasing
summary: It is shown that using paraphrased references does generally improve BLEU, and when it does, the more diverse the better, but it is also shown that better results could be achieved if those paraphrases were to specifically target the parts of the space most relevant to the MT outputs being evaluated.
venue: Findings
authors: Rachel Bawden,Biao Zhang,Lisa Yankovskaya,Andre Tattar,Matt Post

title: Fine-Grained Linguistic Soft Constraints on Statistical Natural Language Processing Models
summary: This dissertation gainfully applies fine-grained linguistic soft constraints - of syntactic or semantic nature - on statistical NLP models, evaluated in end-to-end state-of-the-art statistical machine translation (SMT) systems.

title: A Survey of Paraphrasing and Textual Entailment Methods
summary: Key ideas from the two areas of paraphrasing and textual entailment are summarized by considering in turn recognition, generation, and extraction methods, also pointing to prominent articles and resources.
venue: Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research

title: Paraphrasing Training Data for Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This paper shows how training data can be expanded by paraphrasing one side of a parallel corpus by parsing then generating using an open-source, precise HPSG-based grammar, and shows consistent, statistically-significant gains on training data sets.
authors: Eric Nichols,Francis Bond,D. S. Appling,Yuji Matsumoto

title: Error Driven Paraphrase Annotation using Mechanical Turk
summary: An Amazon Mechanical Turk study is reported on that explores error driven paraphrasing of source sentences, and establishes via an oracle evaluation that it holds the potential to substantially improve translation quality.
venue: Mturk@HLT-NAACL

title: Paraphrases and Applications
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Generating Phrasal and Sentential Paraphrases: A Survey of Data-Driven Methods
summary: A comprehensive and application-independent survey of data-driven phrasal and sentential paraphrase generation methods is conducted, while also conveying an appreciation for the importance and potential use of paraphrases in the field of NLP research.
venue: Computational Linguistics

title: PEM: A Paraphrase Evaluation Metric Exploiting Parallel Texts
summary: PEM is the first fully automatic metric to evaluate the quality of paraphrases, and consequently, that of paraphrase generation systems, based on three criteria: adequacy, fluency, and lexical dissimilarity.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Example-Based Paraphrasing for Improved Phrase-Based Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This proposal is grounded on two main ideas: first, that appropriate examples of a given phrase should participate more in building its translation distribution; second, that paraphrases can be used to better estimate this distribution.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Informal Language Crowdsourcing and Translation
PARAPHRASE AND TEXTUAL ENTAILMENT RECOGNITION AND GENERATION
Incorporating Source-Language Paraphrases into Phrase-Based SMT with Confusion Networks
summary: This paper uses word lattices to build word confusion networks for merging of duplicated paths and faster decoding on English-Chinese translation tasks, and shows that compared with the word-lattice-based method, the decoding time is reduced significantly while comparable translation quality is obtained on the large-scale task.
venue: SSST@ACL

title: A Generate and Rank Approach to Sentence Paraphrasing
summary: Experimental results show that incorporating features from an existing paraphrase recognizer in the ranking component improves performance, and that the overall method compares well against a state of the art paraphrase generator, when paraphrasing rules apply to the input sentences.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Etude de la paraphrase sous-phrastique en traitement automatique des langues
Measuring the Adequacy of Cross-Lingual Paraphrases in a Machine Translation Setting
summary: The results show the strong dependence of cross-lingual paraphrase adequacy on the translation context and cast doubt on the contribution that systems performing well in existing evaluation schemes would have on Machine Translation.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: User Behaviors Lend a Helping Hand: Learning Paraphrase Query Patterns from Search Log Sessions
summary: This paper learns paraphrase patterns from the search log sessions with a classification framework, in which three types of user behavior features are exploited besides the conventional features, to distinguish paraphrases from the simply related queries in the sessions.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Distributional phrasal paraphrase generation for statistical machine translation
summary: It is shown that using distributional paraphrasing can yield greater gains in translation tasks, and implementation details, complexity analysis, and further insight into this method are provided.
venue: TIST

title: Generating targeted paraphrases for improved translation
summary: A novel way to generate “targeted” paraphrases that yields substantially larger gains in translation quality when compared to the previous solution, and is validated by supplementing with human preference judgments obtained via Amazon Mechanical Turk.
venue: TIST

title: FUN-NRC: Paraphrase-augmented Phrase-based SMT Systems for NTCIR-10 PatentMT
summary: This paper describes FUN-NRC group’s machine translation systems that participated in the NTCIR-10 PatentMT task to clarify the potential of automatically compiled collections of sub-sentential paraphrases and investigates two methods for phrase table augmentation.
venue: NTCIR Conference on Evaluation of Information Access Technologies

title: Multilingual WSD-like Constraints for Paraphrase Extraction
summary: This work proposes a novel approach that is able to extract paraphrases by pivoting through multiple languages while discriminating word senses in the input language, i.e., the language to be paraphrased.
venue: Conference on Computational Natural Language Learning

title: Role of Paraphrases in PB-SMT
summary: A convenient way to handle OOV and rare words using paraphrasing technique is proposed and integration of paraphrases into PB-SMT system results in significant improvement.
venue: Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics

title: Paraphrasing Towards Better Search by Incorporating Coordinate Relationship
summary: This work proposes a method to acquire paraphrases from the Web in accordance with a given sentence query, aimed at improving the poor performance of querying the Web by long queries, especially sentence queries, since they often result in failure.

title: Finding Paraphrase Facts Based on Coordinate Relationships
summary: This work proposes a method to acquire paraphrases from the Web in accordance with a given sentence, aiming at finding sentence-level paraphrasing from the noisy Web, instead of domain-specific corpora.
venue: DASFAA Workshops

title: Improving Statistical Machine Translation with a Multilingual Paraphrase Database
summary: It is shown that a graph propagation approach that uses PPDB paraphrases can be used to improve overall translation quality and outperforms the use of distributional profiles from monolingual source data.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Paraphrases for Statistical Machine Translation
summary: It is shown that a graph propagation approach that uses PPDB paraphrases can be used to improve overall translation quality and improves on the state of the art in three different settings: when faced with limited amount of parallel training data; a domain shift between training and test data; and handling a morphologically complex source language.

title: Paraphrase identification using knowledge-lean techniques
summary: It can be surmised that languages poor in resources can benefit from knowledge-lean techniques, as these techniques do not require any language specific tools or external resources and appear to perform well without the need to normalise colloquial language such as that found on Twitter.

title: Learning Query Paraphrasing from A Monolingual Corpus
summary: An extension to the continuous bag-of-words (CBOW) model is presented that efficiently learns the embedding for each template, so that semantically similar templates are detected in such a way that their semantic representations are similar to each other.

title: Knowledge-lean Paraphrase Identification Using Character-Based Features
summary: It is shown that SVM classifiers may be trained to distinguish paraphrase and non-paraphrase pairs across a number of different paraphrase corpora with good results, and analysis shows that features derived from character bigrams are particularly informative.

title: Robust Tuning Datasets for Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This paper achieves the idea of automatically crafting a tuning dataset for Statistical Machine Translation that makes the hyper-parameters of the SMT system more robust with respect to some specific deficiencies of the parameter tuning algorithms by selecting a subset of the available sentence pairs, which are more suitable for specific combinations of optimizers, objective functions, and evaluation measures.
venue: Recent Advances in Natural Language Processing

title: Paraphrase Generation as Unsupervised Machine Translation
summary: A new paradigm for paraphrase generation is proposed by treating the task as unsupervised machine translation (UMT) based on the assumption that there must be pairs of sentences expressing the same meaning in a large-scale unlabeled monolingual corpus.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics
authors: Chun Fan,Yufei Tian,Yuxian Meng,Nanyun Peng,Xiaofei Sun,Fei Wu,Jiwei Li

title: What’s in a domain?: Towards fine-grained adaptation for machine translation
summary: By studying what's in a domain and showing how to use different aspects of language to improve MT, this thesis takes a step forward towards fine-grained adaptation for machine translation.

title: CROSS-MODEL BACK-TRANSLATED DISTILLATION
summary: This work introduces a novel component to the standard UMT framework called Cross-model Back-translated Distillation (CBD), aimed to induce another level of data diversification that existing principles lack, and shows that CBD is effective because it embraces data diversity while other similar variants do not.

title: Data Diversification: A Simple Strategy For Neural Machine Translation
summary: Data Diversification: a simple but effective strategy to boost neural machine translation (NMT) performance by using the predictions of multiple forward and backward models and then merging them with the original dataset on which the final NMT model is trained is introduced.
venue: Neural Information Processing Systems
authors: Xuan-Phi Nguyen,Shafiq R. Joty,Wu Kui,A. Aw

title: Multi-Agent Cross-Translated Diversification for Unsupervised Machine Translation
summary: Multi-Agent Cross-translated Diversification (MACD) is introduced, a method that trains multiple UMT agents and then translates monolingual data back and forth using non-duplicative agents to acquire synthetic parallel data for supervised MT.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Xuan-Phi Nguyen,Shafiq R. Joty,Wu Kui,A. Aw

title: Cross-model Back-translated Distillation for Unsupervised Machine Translation
summary: This work introduces a novel component to the standard UMT framework called Cross-model Back-translated Distillation (CBD), aimed to induce another level of data diversification that existing principles lack and shows that CBD is effective because it embraces data diversity while other similar variants do not.
venue: International Conference on Machine Learning
authors: Xuan-Phi Nguyen,Shafiq R. Joty,Wu Kui,A. Aw

title: Improving Simultaneous Machine Translation with Monolingual Data
summary: This work proposes a novel monolingual sampling strategy for SiMT, considering both chunk length and monotonicity, and achieves +0.72 BLEU improvements on average against random sampling on En-Zh and En-Ja.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Hexuan Deng,Liang Ding,Xuebo Liu,Meishan Zhang,Dacheng Tao,Min Zhang

title: Improving Paraphrase Detection with the Adversarial Paraphrasing Task
summary: A new adversarial method of dataset creation for paraphrase identification is introduced: the Adversarial Paraphrasing Task (APT), which asks participants to generate semantically equivalent but lexically and syntactically disparate paraphrases.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Improving the Diversity of Unsupervised Paraphrasing with Embedding Outputs
summary: An end-to-end multilingual paraphrasing model that is trained using translated parallel corpora to generate paraphrases into “meaning spaces” is presented – replacing the final softmax layer with word embeddings, enabling effective parameter sharing across languages for more fluent monolingual rewriting.
venue: MRL

title: Exploiting Semantic and Syntactic Diversity for Diverse Task-oriented Dialogue
summary: This paper aims to improve the diversity of task-oriented dialogues from both semantic and syntactic perspectives by proposing a structural causal model to learn the causality composition of the dialogue acts and Syntactic forms.
venue: IEEE International Joint Conference on Neural Network
authors: Yajing Sun,Yue Hu,Luxi Xing,Yuqiang Xie,Wei Peng,Yunpeng Li

title: Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Data Augmentation
summary: A data augmentation approach to fill such incomplete parts using multi-source neural machine translation (NMT) is proposed, which varied over different language combinations but significant gains were observed when using a source language similar to the target language.
venue: International Workshop on Spoken Language Translation

title: Ju n 20 19 Robust Machine Translation with Domain Sensitive Pseudo-Sources : Baidu-OSU WMT 19 MT Robustness Shared Task System Report
summary: This paper generates a parallel dataset with pseudo noisy source sentences which are back-translated from monolingual data using a model trained by a similar domain sensitive way and achieves more than 10 BLEU improvement in both En-Fr and Fr-En translation compared with the baseline methods.

title: Robust Machine Translation with Domain Sensitive Pseudo-Sources: Baidu-OSU WMT19 MT Robustness Shared Task System Report
summary: A domain sensitive training method is used which leverages a large amount of parallel data from popular domains together with a little amount of Parallel data from social media to achieve more than 10 BLEU improvement in both En-Fr and Fr-En translation compared with the baseline methods.
venue: Conference on Machine Translation
authors: Renjie Zheng,Hairong Liu,Mingbo Ma,Baigong Zheng,Liang Huang

title: Understanding Data Augmentation in Neural Machine Translation: Two Perspectives towards Generalization
summary: Inspired by recent theoretic advances in deep learning, the paper understands DA from two perspectives towards the generalization ability of a model: input sensitivity and prediction margin, which are defined independent of specific test set thereby may lead to findings with relatively low variance.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
authors: Guanlin Li,Lemao Liu,Guoping Huang,Conghui Zhu,T. Zhao

title: Neural Machine Translation: A Review and Survey
summary: This work traces back the origins of modern NMT architectures to word and sentence embeddings and earlier examples of the encoder-decoder network family and concludes with a survey of recent trends in the field.

title: Multi-Source Neural Machine Translation with Missing Data
summary: This study focuses on the use of incomplete multilingual corpora in multi-encoder NMT and mixture of NMT experts and examines a very simple implementation where missing source translations are replaced by a special symbol.
venue: IEEE/ACM Transactions on Audio Speech and Language Processing

title: Neural Machine Translation: A Review
summary: This work traces back the origins of modern NMT architectures to word and sentence embeddings and earlier examples of the encoder-decoder network family and concludes with a survey of recent trends in the field.
venue: Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research

title: The Roles of Language Models and Hierarchical Models in Neural Sequence-to-Sequence Prediction
summary: It is shown how traditional symbolic statistical machine translation models can still improve neural machine translation while reducing the risk of common pathologies of NMT such as hallucinations and neologisms.
venue: European Association for Machine Translation Conferences/Workshops

title: T ARGET -S IDE I NPUT A UGMENTATION FOR S EQUENCE TO S EQUENCE G ENERATION
summary: This work proposes a target-side augmentation method for sequence generation by using the decoder output probability distributions as soft indicators, which are multiplied with target token embeddings, to build pseudo tokens.
authors: Shufang Xie,Ang Lv,Yingce Xia,Lijun Wu,Tao Qin,Tie-Yan Liu,Rui Yan

title: Mitigating Data Scarceness through Data Synthesis, Augmentation and Curriculum for Abstractive Summarization
summary: This paper introduces a method of data synthesis with paraphrasing, a data augmentation technique with sample mixing, and curriculum learning with two new difficulty metrics based on specificity and abstractiveness.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Conciseness: An Overlooked Language Task
summary: It is demonstrated that conciseness is a difficult task for which zero-shot setups with large neural language models often do not perform well, and a synthetic data generation method based on round-trip translations is proposed.
venue: TSAR

title: Negative Lexically Constrained Decoding for Paraphrase Generation
summary: A neural model is proposed for paraphrase generation that first identifies words in the source sentence that should be paraphrased and then these words are paraphrasing by the negative lexically constrained decoding that avoids outputting these words as they are.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: An Empirical Study on Model-agnostic Debiasing Strategies for Robust Natural Language Inference
summary: This paper benchmarks prevailing neural NLI models including pretrained ones on various adversarial datasets and tries to combat distinct known biases by modifying a mixture of experts (MoE) ensemble method and shows that it’s nontrivial to mitigate multiple NLI biases at the same time, and that model-level ensemble method outperforms MoE ensemble method.
venue: Conference on Computational Natural Language Learning
authors: Tianyu Liu,Xin Zheng,Xiaoan Ding,Baobao Chang,Zhifang Sui

title: Iterative Paraphrastic Augmentation with Discriminative Span Alignment
summary: A novel paraphrastic augmentation strategy based on sentence-level lexically constrained paraphrasing and discriminative span alignment that allows for the large-scale expansion of existing datasets or the rapid creation of new datasets using a small, manually produced seed corpus.
venue: Transactions of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Ryan Culkin,J. E. Hu,Elias Stengel-Eskin,Guanghui Qin,Benjamin Van Durme

title: Automatically Paraphrasing via Sentence Reconstruction and Round-trip Translation
summary: A novel framework for paraphrase generation that simultaneously decodes the output sentence using a pretrained wordset-to-sequence model and a round-trip translation model is proposed and used to augment the training data for machine translation to achieve substantial improvements.
venue: International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence
authors: Zilu Guo,Zhongqiang Huang,Kenny Q. Zhu,Guandan Chen,Kaibo Zhang,Boxing Chen,Fei Huang

title: ConRPG: Paraphrase Generation using Contexts as Regularizer
summary: A pipelined system which consists of paraphrase candidate generation based on contextual language models, candidate filtering using scoring functions, and paraphrase model training based on the selected candidates, which significantly outperforms existing paraphrase approaches in both supervised and unsupervised setups.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
authors: Yuxian Meng,Xiang Ao,Qing He,Xiaofei Sun,Qinghong Han,Fei Wu,Chun Fan,Jiwei Li

title: Constraint-embedded paraphrase generation for commercial tweets
summary: A Constraint-Embedded Language Modeling (CELM) framework, in which hard constraints are embedded in the text content and learned through a language model, is proposed, which is shown to outperform general paraphrase generation models as well as the state-of-the-art CopyNet model, in terms of paraphrase similarity, diversity, and the ability to conform to hard constraints.
venue: International Conference on Advances in Social Networks Analysis and Mining

title: Parallel Decoders Guided Lexically Constrained Response Generation
summary: This paper proposes the novel Parallel Decoders to guide response modification and achieves better performance than the state-of-the-art generation models in terms of constraint relevance, sentence fluency, response diversity and human evaluation.
venue: 2021 IEEE International Conference on Big Data (Big Data)
authors: Daixuan Cheng,Haifeng Sun,Q. Qi,Jingyu Wang,Yan Qi

title: A Fuzzy Training Framework for Controllable Sequence-to-Sequence Generation
summary: A fuzzy training framework is proposed that allows a model to simultaneously support both unrestricted and restricted translation by adopting an additional auxiliary training process without constraining the decoding process, thus improving its practicality and achieving the goal of green AI.
venue: IEEE Access
authors: Jiajia Li,P. Wang,Z. Li,Xi Liu,M. Utiyama,E. Sumita,Hai Zhao,H. Ai

title: Entailment Relation Aware Paraphrase Generation
summary: This work proposes a reinforcement learning-based weakly-supervised paraphrasing system, ERAP, that can be trained using existing paraphrase and natural language inference corpora without an explicit task-specific corpus and generates paraphrases conforming to the specified entailment relation.
venue: AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence

title: A BILINGUAL GENERATIVE TRANSFORMER
summary: A deep latent variable model is proposed that attempts to perform source separation on parallel sentences, isolating what they have in common in a latent semantic vector, and explaining what is left over with language-specific latent vectors.

title: Beyond BLEU:Training Neural Machine Translation with Semantic Similarity
summary: An alternative reward function for optimizing NMT systems that is based on recent work in semantic similarity is introduced, and it is found that training with the proposed metric results in better translations as evaluated by BLEU, semantic similarity, and human evaluation, and that the optimization procedure converges faster.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: A Bilingual Generative Transformer for Semantic Sentence Embedding
summary: A deep latent variable model is proposed that attempts to perform source separation on parallel sentences, isolating what they have in common in a latent semantic vector, and explaining what is left over with language-specific latent vectors.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Experiments on Paraphrase Identification Using Quora Question Pairs Dataset
summary: This work modeled the Quora question pairs dataset to identify a similar question with up to 97 percent accuracy and experimented with WordPiece tokenizer which improves the model performance significantly.
venue: arXiv.org

title: Exemplar-Controllable Paraphrasing and Translation using Bitext
summary: This work adapts models from prior work to be able to learn solely from bilingual text (bitext), and shows that their models learn to disentangle semantics and syntax in their latent representations, but still suffer from semantic drift.

title: Controllable Paraphrasing and Translation with a Syntactic Exemplar
summary: The authors' single proposed model can perform four tasks: controlled paraphrase generation in both languages and controlled machine translation in both language directions, and analysis shows that their models learn to disentangle semantics and syntax in their latent representations.
venue: arXiv.org

title: Self-training Improves Pre-training for Natural Language Understanding
summary: SentAugment, a data augmentation method which computes task-specific query embeddings from labeled data to retrieve sentences from a bank of billions of unlabeled sentences crawled from the web, is introduced.
venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Jingfei Du,Edouard Grave,Beliz Gunel,Vishrav Chaudhary,Onur Çelebi,Michael Auli,V. Stoyanov,Alexis Conneau

title: Disentangling Semantics and Syntax in Sentence Embeddings with Pre-trained Language Models
summary: ParaBART is a semantic sentence embedding model that learns to disentangle semantics and syntax in sentence embeddings obtained by pre-trained language models, and can effectively remove syntactic information from semantic sentenceembeddings, leading to better robustness against syntactic variation on downstream semantic tasks.
venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Paraphrastic Representations at Scale
summary: The resulting models surpass all prior work on unsupervised semantic textual similarity, significantly outperforming even BERT-based models like Sentence-BERT and can be used on CPU with little difference in inference speed, making these models an attractive choice for users without access to GPUs or for use on embedded devices.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: On the Effectiveness of Sentence Encoding for Intent Detection Meta-Learning
summary: This paper conducts empirical studies on a number of general-purpose sentence embedding schemes, showing that good sentence embeddings without any fine-tuning on intent detection data could produce a non-trivially strong performance.
venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Tingting Ma,Qianhui Wu,Zhiwei Yu,T. Zhao,Chin-Yew Lin

title: NMTScore: A Multilingual Analysis of Translation-based Text Similarity Measures
summary: Compared to baselines such as sentence embeddings, translation-based measures prove competitive in paraphrase identification and are more robust against adversarial or multilingual input, especially if proper normalization is applied.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Retrofitting Multilingual Sentence Embeddings with Abstract Meaning Representation
summary: Experimental results show that retrofitting multilingual sentence embeddings with AMR leads to better state-of-the-art performance on both semantic textual similarity and transfer tasks.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
authors: Deng Cai,Xin Li,Jackie Chun-Sing Ho,Lidong Bing,W. Lam

title: Unsupervised Paraphrasing without Translation
summary: This work proposes to learn paraphrasing models only from a monolingual corpus, and proposes a residual variant of vector-quantized variational auto-encoder, which is shown to outperform unsupervised translation in all contexts.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Text-to-text generation by monolingual machine translation
Unsupervised Verb Inference from Nouns Crossing Root Boundary
summary: A new online resource PreDic (PREdicate DICtionary) is presented that contains verbs inferred from nouns sharing similar concepts but not the root that performs similar to or better than WordNet and NOMLEX.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: BLEU Might Be Guilty but References Are Not Innocent
summary: This paper develops a paraphrasing task for linguists to perform on existing reference translations, which counteracts this bias and reveals that multi-reference BLEU does not improve the correlation for high quality output, and presents an alternative multi- reference formulation that is more effective.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Traitement automatique des langues et génération automatique d'exercices de grammaire. (Automatic language processing and automatic generation of grammar exercises)
summary: La representation formelle de l'information dans un cadre linguistique particulier a une langue est une tâche ardue, en combinant divers modeles, that permet d'exploiter un corpus sous differents angles, augmentant la diversite des sorties, exploitant les leviers syntaxiques mis en place.

title: Human-Paraphrased References Improve Neural Machine Translation
summary: This work confirms the finding that paraphrased references yield metric scores that correlate better with human judgment, and demonstrates for the first time that using these scores for system development can lead to significant improvements.
venue: Conference on Machine Translation
authors: Markus Freitag,George F. Foster,David Grangier,Colin Cherry

title: Research Synopsis
summary: My research lies in the area of Natural Language Processing (NLP), a highly interdisciplinary field of study comprising of concepts and ideas from Artificial Intelligence, Linguistic Theory and Statistics.

title: Fluency, Adequacy, or HTER? Exploring Different Human Judgments with a Tunable MT Metric
summary: TER-Plus is explored, which is a new tunable MT metric that extends the Translation Edit Rate evaluation metric with tunable parameters and the incorporation of morphology, synonymy and paraphrases, demonstrating significant differences between the types of human judgments.
venue: WMT@EACL
authors: Matthew G. Snover,Nitin Madnani,B. Dorr,R. Schwartz

title: Part 5: Machine Translation Evaluation Chapter 5.1 Introduction
summary: The development and use of automatic, human, task-based and semi-automatic methods of evaluating machine translation, focusing on the use of a human-mediated translation error rate HTER as the evaluation standard used in GALE are discussed.

title: Handbook of Natural Language Processing and Machine Translation: DARPA Global Autonomous Language Exploitation
summary: This comprehensive handbook, written by leading experts in the field, details the groundbreaking research conducted under the breakthrough GALE program--The Global Autonomous Language Exploitation within the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), while placing it in the context of previous research in the fields of natural language and signal processing, artificial intelligence and machine translation.

title: Une étude en 3D de la paraphrase: types de corpus, langues et techniques (A Study of Paraphrase along 3 Dimensions : Corpus Types, Languages and Techniques) [in French]
summary: This paper reports a detailed study of the impact of corpus type on the task of sub-sentential paraphrase acquisition and obtains relative improvements over the combination system over the best individual system on English and French.
venue: JEP/TALN/RECITAL

title: Generalizing Sub-sentential Paraphrase Acquisition across Original Signal Type of Text Pairs
summary: A corpus of 2,500 annotated sentences in English and French is described, and performance on this corpus is reported for an efficient system combination exploiting a large set of features for paraphrase recognition.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Systematic Comparison of Professional and Crowdsourced Reference Translations for Machine Translation
summary: This work compares Machine Translation systems trained on the same data but with translations obtained using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk vs. professional translations, and shows that the same performance is obtained from Mechanical Turk translations at 1/5th the cost.
venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Rabih Zbib,Gretchen Markiewicz,S. Matsoukas,R. Schwartz,J. Makhoul

title: Improving Adversarial Neural Machine Translation for Morphologically Rich Language
summary: An extended version of GAN model for neural machine translation is proposed to optimize the performance of morphologically rich language translation by using the morphological word embedding instead of word embedded as input in GANmodel to enrich the representation of words and overcome the data sparsity problem during model training.
venue: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence

title: Paraphrasing and translation
summary: A novel technique for automatically generating paraphrases using bilingual parallel corpora, which are more commonly used as training data for statistical models of translation, and can be applied to any language which has a parallel corpus.

title: AUTOMATED PARAPHRASING FOR AUTHORING AIDS AND MACHINE TRANSLATION
Combining Multiple Resources to Improve SMT-based Paraphrasing Model
summary: Experimental results show that the SMT-based paraphrasing model can be enhanced using multiple resources, and the phrase-level and sentence-level precision of the generated paraphrases are above 60% and 55%, respectively.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Shiqi Zhao,Cheng Niu,M. Zhou,Ting Liu,Sheng Li

title: Syntactic Constraints on Paraphrases Extracted from Parallel Corpora
summary: This work improves the quality of paraphrases extracted from parallel corpora by requiring that phrases and their paraphrasing be the same syntactic type and altering the phrase extraction algorithm to extract phrase labels alongside bilingual phrase pairs.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Research on Paraphrasing Technology
summary: The state-of-the-art research on paraphrasing in natural language processing is surveyed, including the applications, the acquisition of resources, the generation, and the evaluation of paraphrases, as well as some closely related topics.

title: Improved Statistical Machine Translation with Hybrid Phrasal Paraphrases Derived from Monolingual Text and a Shallow Lexical Resource
summary: Evaluated in statistical machine translation tasks by augmenting translation models with paraphrase-based translation rules, it is shown the novel technique is superior to the non-augmented baseline and both the distributional and pivot paraphrasing techniques.
venue: Conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas

title: Moving Beyond Phrase Pairs: The Relevance of the Corpus in a SMT World
summary: This work proposes modeling each instance of a translation in the corpus as a mixture of translation instances, which moves translation beyond the concept of static, discrete translation entities and permits a more fluid assessment of each translation instance.

title: Learning an Expert from Human Annotations in Statistical Machine Translation: the Case of Out-of-Vocabulary Words
summary: Results of experiments on English-French translation show that this method outperforms previous work addressing OOV words in terms of acceptability and active learning is used to discriminatively train the model parameters from human assessments of the quality of translations.
venue: European Association for Machine Translation Conferences/Workshops

title: Structured Probabilistic Models for Natural Language Semantics
summary: This thesis proposal studies structured probabilistic models tailored to solve problems in computational semantics, with a focus on modeling structure that is not visible in annotated text data, and proposes to leverage large volumes of unlabeled data to improve upon the aforementioned tasks.

title: Discriminative training and variational decoding in machine translation via novel algorithms for weighted hypergraphs
summary: This dissertation presents two unsupervised discriminative training methods: minimum imputed-risk training, and contrastive language model estimation, both of which can exploit monolingual English data to perform discrim inative training.

title: Hitting the Right Paraphrases in Good Time
summary: Manual evaluation of generated output shows that the random-walk-based approach to learning paraphrases from bilingual parallel corpora outperforms the state-of-the-art system of Callison-Burch (2008).
venue: North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Interlingual annotation of parallel text corpora: a new framework for annotation and evaluation
summary: The work described below constitutes the first effort of any kind to annotate multiple translations of foreign-language texts with interlingual content, with three levels of representation: deep syntactic dependencies, intermediate semantic representations, and a normalized representation that unifies conversives, nonliteral language, and paraphrase.
venue: Natural Language Engineering
authors: B. Dorr,R. Passonneau,D. Farwell,R. Green,Nizar Habash,Stephen Helmreich,E. Hovy,Lori S. Levin,K. Miller,T. Mitamura,Owen Rambow,Advaith Siddharthan

title: Paraphrase Lattice for Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This paper shows that lattice decoding is also useful for handling input variations, and shows that the proposed method obtains significant gains in BLEU scores.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Make It Simple with Paraphrases
summary: This book presents a novel scientific approach to improve machine translation by paraphrasing support verb constructions with semantically equivalent verbs (e.g. make a presentation of/present), presenting obvious benefits to linguistic quality assurance in text processing.

title: Phrase Clustering for Smoothing TM Probabilities - or, How to Extract Paraphrases from Phrase Tables
summary: This paper incorporated phrase-cluster-derived probability estimates into a baseline loglinear feature combination that included relative frequency and lexically-weighted conditional probability estimates, and looked at one of these uses: smoothing the conditional translation model (TM) probabilities employed by the SMT system.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics
authors: R. Kuhn,Boxing Chen,George F. Foster,Evan Stratford

title: Unsupervised Discriminative Language Model Training for Machine Translation using Simulated Confusion Sets
summary: An unsupervised discriminative training procedure is proposed for estimating a language model (LM) for machine translation (MT) and promising improvements on a state-of-the-art MT system are demonstrated.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Monolingual Distributional Profiles for Word Substitution in Machine Translation
summary: This work shows how to handle not just the OOV words but rare words as well in an Example-based Machine Translation (EBMT) paradigm, and introduces a new framework to score and rank the replacements by efficiently combining features extracted for the candidate replacements.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Coping with data-sparsity in example-based machine translation
summary: An algorithm is used to find possible replacements which are not necessarily synonyms to replace out-of-vocabulary words as well as rare words based on the context in which these words appear.

title: Collecting Comparable Corpora from the Web
summary: This work uses News articles published on the Web to gather a large amount of comparable corpora for a number of different languages including English, German, Croatian, Estonian, Latvian, Romanian, Greek and Slovenian and reports the initial results.

title: Semantic smoothing and fabrication of phrase pairs for SMT
summary: A new soft clustering method to smooth the conditional translation probabilities for a given phrase with those of semantically similar phrases is proposed, called semantic smoothing (SS).
venue: International Workshop on Spoken Language Translation

title: Searching Translation Memories for Paraphrases
summary: The paraphrase pairs used in this system are obtained from parallel corpora and are used to retrieve sentences in a statistical framework and can retrieve sentences that have the same meaning as the input sentences even if they do not match exactly.
venue: Machine Translation Summit

title: Filtering Antonymous, Trend-Contrasting, and Polarity-Dissimilar Distributional Paraphrases for Improving Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This work presents a novel method for improving distributional paraphrasing by filtering out antonyms, trend-contrasting, and polarity-dissimilar candidates as good paraphrases, evaluated in simulated low and mid-resourced SMT tasks, translating from English to two quite different languages.
venue: WMT@EMNLP

title: Enriching SMT Training Data via Paraphrasing
summary: This paper proposes a novel method to resolve the coverage problem of SMT system by employing an object function, named Sentence Novelty, to select paraphrases which having the most novel information to the bilingual training corpus of the SMT model.
venue: International Joint Conference on Natural Language Processing

title: Modeling Relevance in Statistical Machine Translation: Scoring Alignment, Context, and Annotations of Translation Instances
summary: This work improves upon the state-of-the-art in machine translation with an instance-based model that scores each instance of translation in the corpus, and implements this approach in Cunei, a new platform for machine translation that permits the scoring of instance-specific features.

title: Semi-Supervised and Latent-Variable Models of Natural Language Semantics
summary: This dissertation studies statistical models tailored to solve problems in computational semantics, with a focus on modeling structure that is not visible in annotated text data, and presents methods to leverage large volumes of unlabeled data to improve upon the shallow semantic parsing task.

title: Computational Linguistics and Intelligent Text Processing
summary: Details of two systems are presented, first, a speech driven question answering system and second, a dialog modeling system, both of which reflect the theme of tightly incorporating constraints across multiple components to improve the accuracy of their tasks.
venue: Lecture Notes in Computer Science

title: SMT Quality with Automatically Extracted Paraphrase Rules
summary: A novel approach to improve SMT via paraphrase rules which are automatically extracted from the bilingual training data by comparing the source side of the parallel corpus with the target-to-source translations of the target side.

title: Alignment of narrative retellings for automated neuropsychological assessment
summary: This document summarizes current capabilities, research and operational priorities, and plans for further studies that were established at the 2015 USGS workshop on quantitative hazard assessments of earthquake-triggered landsliding and liquefaction in the Czech Republic.

title: Examining Linguistic Characteristics of Paraphrase in Test-Taker Summaries
Building Subjectivity Lexicon(s) from Scratch for Essay Data
summary: The process of constructing subjectivity lexicon(s) for recognizing sentiment polarity in essays written by test-takers, to be used within a commercial essay-scoring system are described.
venue: Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics
authors: Beata Beigman Klebanov,J. Burstein,Nitin Madnani,Adam Faulkner,J. Tetreault

title: A light way to collect comparable corpora from the Web
summary: It is shown experimentally that titles can be used to approximate the comparison between documents using full document contents, and the amount of time and resources spent for tasks 1 and 2 is reduced.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation

title: Turkish Paraphrase Corpus
summary: The first Turkish paraphrase corpus is presented and all paraphrase pairs are carefully annotated by native Turkish speakers with the identified semantic correspondences between paraphrases.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation
authors: Seniz Demir,Ilknur Durgar El-Kahlout,E. Ünal,Hamza Kaya

title: Improve SMT Quality with Automatically Extracted Paraphrase Rules
summary: A novel approach to improve SMT via paraphrase rules which are automatically extracted from the bilingual training data by comparing the source side of the parallel corpus with the target-to-source translations of the target side.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Enlarging Paraphrase Collections through Generalization and Instantiation
summary: A paraphrase acquisition method that uncovers and exploits generalities underlying paraphrases: paraphrase patterns are first induced and then used to collect novel instances, which uses both bilingual parallel and monolingual corpora.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing

title: Enriching Parallel Corpora for Statistical Machine Translation with Semantic Negation Rephrasing
summary: An approach to improving performance of statistical machine translation by automatically creating new training data for difficult to translate phenomena by automatically rephrasing existing sentences to their negated counterparts making use of semantic transfer is presented.
venue: SSST@ACL

title: A Simplification-Translation-Restoration Framework for Cross-Domain SMT Applications
summary: A simplification-translation-restoration (STR) framework for domain adaptation in SMT by simplifying domain specific segments of a text by identifying the critical segments and modifying them to alleviate the data sparseness problem in the out-domain SMT system.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Deriving Paraphrases for Highly Inflected Languages from Comparable Documents
summary: An automatic paraphrase-inference procedure for a highly inflected language like Arabic, with two classifiers, one designed to model the contexts surrounding occurrences of paraphrases, and the other trained to identify significant features of the words within paraphrase.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Automatic Bilingual Phrase Extraction from Comparable Corpora
summary: This work presents an approach for extracting parallel phrases from comparable news articles to improve statistical machine translation, particularly useful for under-resourced languages where parallel corpora are not readily available.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: Confidence-driven Rewriting for Improved Translation
summary: This work presents an approach, and an interactive tool implementing it, where source sentences are rewritten in order to maximize confidence estimates with respect to the translation model, and automatically-generated rewritings are then proposed for the user’s approval.
venue: Machine Translation Summit

title: Recognizing Textual Entailment: Models and Applications
summary: This book discusses the development of knowledge acquisition techniques in the field of text-based learning and discusses their applications in the context of education and research.
venue: Recognizing Textual Entailment: Models and Applications
authors: Ido Dagan,D. Roth,M. Sammons,Fabio Massimo Zanzotto

title: Using targeted paraphrasing and monolingual crowdsourcing to improve translation
summary: Formal evaluation demonstrates that this approach can yield substantial improvements in translation quality, and the idea has been integrated into a broader framework for monolingual collaborative translation that produces fully accurate, fully fluent translations for a majority of sentences in a real-world translation task, with no involvement of human bilingual speakers.
venue: TIST
authors: P. Resnik,Olivia Buzek,Y. Kronrod,Chang Hu,Alexander J. Quinn,B. Bederson

title: LEVERAGING DIVERSE SOURCES IN STATISTICAL MACHINE TRANSLATION
summary: The experimental results show that ensemble decoding outperforms various strong baselines including mixture models, the current state-of-the-art for domain adaptation in machine translation.

title: SORT: An Interactive Source-Rewriting Tool for Improved Translation
summary: This paper presents an interactive system where source modifications are induced by confidence estimates that are derived from the translation model in use, and can reduce postediting effort by replacing it by cost-effective pre-editing that can be done by monolinguals.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Graph Propagation for Paraphrasing Out-of-Vocabulary Words in Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach to finding translations for oov words by inducing a lexicon by constructing a graph on source language monolingual text and employing a graph propagation technique in order to find translations for all the source language phrases.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Translating Chinese Unknown Words by Automatically Acquired Templates
summary: This paper presents a translation template model, which exploits translation templates, which are extracted automatically from a word-aligned parallel corpus, to translate unknown words to improve the performance of the Moses machine translation system.
venue: International Joint Conference on Natural Language Processing
authors: Ming-Hong Bai,Yu-Ming Hsieh,Keh-Jiann Chen,Jason J. S. Chang

title: Comparabilty of Corpora in Human and Machine Translation
summary: The definition of comparability is revised and it is shown that some notions from translatology, i.e. registerial features, should also be considered in machine translation.

title: Inferring Paraphrases for a Highly Inflected Language from a Monolingual Corpus
summary: A new technique for deriving paraphrases from a monolingual corpus, supported by a relatively small set of comparable documents, is suggested, applied to Arabic, a highly inflected language, for improving an Arabic-to-English statistical translation system.
venue: Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics

title: Semantic Clustering of Pivot Paraphrases
summary: The comparison of the acquired senses to gold data from the Lexical Substitution shared task demonstrates that sense distinctions exist in the paraphrase sets and highlights the need for a disambiguation step in applications using this resource.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation

title: Creating and using large monolingual parallel corpora for sentential paraphrase generation
summary: It is observed that as the paraphrases deviate more from the source sentence, the performance of the PBMT-R system degrades less than that of the word substitution baseline system.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation
authors: S. Wubben,Antal van den Bosch,E. Krahmer

title: Graph-based Semi-Supervised Learning of Translation Models from Monolingual Data
summary: This work presents a semi-supervised graph-based approach for generating new translation rules that leverages bilingual and monolingual data, and significantly improves the performance of competitive phrasebased systems, leading to consistent improvements between 1 and 4 BLEU points on standard evaluation sets.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Avneesh Singh Saluja,Hany Hassan,Kristina Toutanova,Chris Quirk

title: Using Comparable Corpora to Augment Statistical Machine Translation Models in Low Resource Settings
summary: This thesis directly incorporate comparable corpora into the estimation of end-to-end SMT models and shows that doing so improves performance in settings where a limited amount of parallel data is available for training.

title: Sensible: L2 Translation Assistance by Emulating the Manual Post-Editing Process
summary: Post-Editor Z emulates the manual process of post-editing by crawling and extracting parallel sentences that contain the untranslated fragments from a Web-based translation memory and applying simple cosine-based sentence similarity to rank possible translations for theUntranslated fragment.
venue: International Workshop on Semantic Evaluation
authors: Liling Tan,Anne Schumann,José Manuel Martínez Martínez,Francis Bond

title: Text Rewriting Improves Semantic Role Labeling
summary: This paper uses automatically extracted rewrite rules from comparable corpora and bitexts to generate multiple versions of sentences annotated with gold standard labels and shows that a model trained on rewritten data outperforms the state of the art on the CoNLL-2009 benchmark dataset.
venue: Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research

title: Improving Statistical Machine Translation Accuracy Using Bilingual Lexicon Extractionwith Paraphrases
summary: Paraphrases are used to smooth the vectors used in comparable feature estimation with BLE and improve the qual- ity of comparable features, which can improve the accuracy of the translation model thus improving SMT performance.
venue: Pacific Asia Conference on Language, Information and Computation

title: Targeted Paraphrasing of Czech Sentences for Machine Translation Evaluation
summary: This thesis develops and compares several approaches for creating new synthetic references that are closer in wording to a corresponding machine translations that will make evaluation using traditional metrics more reliable as they lack of paraphrase and free word order support.

title: Proposal : Cross-Lingual Transfer of Linguistic and Metalinguistic Knowledge via Lexical Borrowing
Developing a corpus-based paraphrase tool to improve EFL learners' writing skills
summary: The results indicated that PREFER offered the most benefits to students' writing performance (with an after-use improvement of 38.2%), compared with an online dictionary and an online thesaurus (−31.6% and −6.2%, respectively).
authors: Mei-Hua Chen,Shih-Ting Huang,Jason J. S. Chang,Hsien-Chin Liou

title: Automatic compilation of bilingual terminologies from comparable corpora
summary: This work focuses on bilingual terminology induction from freely available comparable corpora, i.e. thematically related documents in two or more languages, and integrates automatically compiled bilingual terminologies with Statistical Machine Translation systems to more accurately translate unknown terms.

title: Integrated Parallel Data Extraction from Comparable Corpora for Statistical Machine Translation
summary: Novel approaches are proposed to extract three types of parallel data from comparable corpora in an integrated framework to improve statistical machine translation and exploit linguistic knowledge of common Chinese characters for Chinese-Japanese parallel data extraction as a case study.

title: Extraction of Potentially Useful Phrase Pairs for Statistical Machine Translation
summary: This paper shows that, for Japanese-English and Chinese-English statistical machine translation systems, this method is indeed missing potentially useful phrase pairs which could lead to better translation scores.
venue: Journal of Information Processing

title: Twitter Paraphrase Identification with Simple Overlap Features and SVMs
summary: The results demonstrate that character and word level overlap features in combination can give performance comparable to methods employing more sophisticated NLP processing tools and external resources.
venue: International Workshop on Semantic Evaluation

title: Lexicon Stratification for Translating Out-of-Vocabulary Words
summary: This paper uses models of lexical borrowing in machine translation as a pivoting mechanism to obtain translations of out-of-vocabulary loanwords in a lowresource language and obtains substantial improvements over standard baselines.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Cross-Lingual Bridges with Models of Lexical Borrowing
summary: This work develops a model of morpho-phonological transformations across languages, based on universal constraints from Optimality Theory, and shows that compared to several standard--but linguistically more naive--baselines, this OT-inspired model obtains good performance at predicting donor forms from borrowed forms with only a few dozen training examples, making this a cost-effective strategy for sharing lexical information across languages.
venue: Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research

title: Language Identification and Disambiguation in Indian Mixed-Script
summary: The algorithm that has been proposed in this paper tries to segregate words from various languages and provide relevant replacements for the misspelled or unknown words in a given query using a list of probabilities of doublets and triplets of words occurring together that are computed from a training database.
venue: International Conference on Distributed Computing and Internet Technology

title: Constructing a Turkish Corpus for Paraphrase Identification and Semantic Similarity
summary: The construction of a paraphrase corpus for Turkish comprises pairs of sentences with semantic similarity scores based on human judgments, permitting experimentation with both PI and semantic similarity.
venue: Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics

title: Creation of comparable corpora for English-Urdu, Arabic, Persian
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation

title: A method of generating translations of unseen n‐grams by using proportional analogy
summary: The experimental results show that unseen n‐grams translations generated using the technique of proportional analogy are rewarding for statistical machine translation systems with small datasets.

title: Paraphrasing Out-of-Vocabulary Words with Word Embeddings and Semantic Lexicons for Low Resource Statistical Machine Translation
summary: Experiments conducted on a low resource setting of the OLYMPICS task of IWSLT 2012 verify the effectiveness of the proposed method using word embeddings and semantic lexicons for OOV paraphrasing.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation

title: Using BabelNet to Improve OOV Coverage in SMT
summary: Experimental results on English―Polish and English―Chinese language pairs show that domain adaptation can better utilize BabelNet knowledge and performs better than other methods, and demonstrate that BabelNet is a really useful tool for improving translation performance of SMT systems.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation

title: Resolving Out-of-Vocabulary Words with Bilingual Embeddings in Machine Translation
summary: A log-bilinear softmax-based model for vocabulary expansion is proposed, such that given an out-of-vocabulary source word, the model generates a probabilistic list of possible translations in the target language.
venue: arXiv.org

title: Explorer Paraphrasing Revisited with Neural Machine Translation
summary: This paper revisits bilingual pivoting in the context of neural machine translation and presents a paraphrasing model based purely on neural networks, showing that neural paraphrases outperform those obtained with conventional phrase-based pivoting approaches.

title: ParaDi: Dictionary of Paraphrases of Czech Complex Predicates with Light Verbs
summary: A new freely available dictionary of paraphrases of Czech complex predicates with light verbs, ParaDi, which demonstrates one of many possible applications of Para Di in an experiment with improving machine translation quality.
venue: MWE@EACL

title: A simplification-translation-restoration framework for domain adaptation in statistical machine translation: A case study in medical record translation
summary: This paper identifies the critical segments in a medical sentence and simplify them to alleviate the data sparseness problem in the out-of-domain SMT system and proposes a simplification–translation–restoration (STR) framework for domain adaptation in SMT systems.
venue: Computer Speech and Language

title: Paraphrasing Revisited with Neural Machine Translation
summary: This paper revisit bilingual pivoting in the context of neural machine translation and presents a paraphrasing model based purely on neural networks, which represents paraphrases in a continuous space, estimates the degree of semantic relatedness between text segments of arbitrary length, and generates candidate paraphrase for any source input.
venue: Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Learning Bilingual Projections of Embeddings for Vocabulary Expansion in Machine Translation
summary: A simple log-bilinear softmax-based model to deal with vocabulary expansion in machine translation, which integrates these translation options into a standard phrase-based statistical machine translation system and gets consistent improvements in translation quality on the English–Spanish language pair.
venue: Rep4NLP@ACL

title: WERD: Using social text spelling variants for evaluating dialectal speech recognition
summary: This work borrows ideas from an MT evaluation metric, namely TERp, an extension of translation error rate which is closely-related to WER, and shows that the resulting WERd (i.e., WER for dialects) metric is more adequate for evaluating dialectal ASR.
venue: Automatic Speech Recognition & Understanding
authors: Ahmed M. Ali,Preslav Nakov,P. Bell,S. Renals

title: A syntactic knowledge constrained paraphrase extraction for Chinese-English statistical machine translation
summary: Results show that the syntactic knowledge-enhanced method to extract higher-quality paraphrases to further improve the quality of statistical machine translation can significantly improve translation performance compared with the baseline system.
venue: ACM Cloud and Autonomic Computing Conference

title: Deep neural networks for identification of sentential relations
summary: This dissertation presents some deep neural networks (DNNs) which are developed to handle sentential relation identification problem, and proposes a dynamic ``attentive pooling'' to select phrase alignments of different intensities for different task categories.

title: Chapter 2 Paraphrases of verbal multiword expressions : the case of Czech light verbs and idioms
summary: The ranking of LVC and IVC abstract units identified in the data, based on their frequency, is shown.

title: Multi-dialect Arabic broadcast speech recognition
summary: English is proposed as a five class dialect challenge comprising of the previously mentioned four dialects as well as modern standard Arabic, and a framework for Arabic ASR that is publicly available for research is addressed.

title: Augmenting Statistical Machine Translation with Subword Translation of Out-of-Vocabulary Words
summary: This work describes and evaluates several general methods for OOV translation that use only subword information and intrinsically evaluates their approaches on fourteen typologically diverse languages across varying resource levels.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Nelson F. Liu,Jonathan May,Michael Pust,Kevin Knight

title: Paraphrase Generation for Semi-Supervised Learning in NLU
summary: This work proposes Para-SSL, a scheme to generate candidate utterances using paraphrasing and methods from semi-supervised learning, which does not require user utterances and can be applied prior to releasing a new functionality to a system.
venue: Proceedings of the Workshop on Methods for Optimizing and Evaluating Neural Language Generation

title: Collecting Comparable Corpora
summary: This chapter presents a review of previous techniques that have been developed and describes in detail three new techniques to gather comparable documents from three different types of Web sources: Wikipedia, news articles, and narrow domains.
venue: Using Comparable Corpora for Under-Resourced Areas of Machine Translation
authors: Monica Lestari Paramita,Ahmet Aker,Paul D. Clough,R. Gaizauskas,Nikos Glaros,Nikos Mastropavlos,O. Yannoutsou,Radu Ion,D. Stefanescu,Alexandru Ceausu,D. Tufis,Judita Preiss

title: Advancing Seq2seq with Joint Paraphrase Learning
summary: This work proposes going beyond data augmentation via paraphrase-optimized multi-task learning and observes that it is useful in correctly handling unseen sentential paraphrases as inputs in sequence to sequence architectures.
venue: Clinical Natural Language Processing Workshop

title: Intrinsic and Extrinsic Automatic Evaluation Strategies for Paraphrase Generation Systems
summary: This study proposes semantic or meaning oriented automatic evaluation metric that helps to evaluate quality of generated paraphrases against the original text, which is an intrinsic evaluation approach and reveals that there is a significant correlation between intrinsic and extrinsic evaluation approaches.
venue: Journal of Computer and Communications
authors: Tulu Tilahun Hailu,Junqing Yu,Tessfu Geteye Fantaye

title: Delexicalized Paraphrase Generation
summary: A neural model for paraphrasing is presented and trained to generate delexicalized sentences and it is shown that natural language understanding tasks, such as intent classification and named entity recognition, can benefit from data augmentation using automatically generated paraphrases.
venue: International Conference on Computational Linguistics

title: A Systematic Literature Review on Extraction of Parallel Corpora from Comparable Corpora
summary: A proposed architecture and a mind map are showcased in this review article to provide better clarity regarding parallel data extraction using comparable corpora to increase readers' understanding of parallel data mining through bilingual lexicons, parallel sentences and fragments.
venue: Journal of Computer Science

title: RuPAWS: A Russian Adversarial Dataset for Paraphrase Identification
summary: RuPAWS is presented, the first adversarial dataset for Russian paraphrase identification and can measure the effectiveness of models to word order and syntax structure since simple baselines fail even when given RuPAWS training samples.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation
authors: Nikita Martynov,I. Krotova,V. Logacheva,A. Panchenko,Olga Kozlova,Nikita Semenov

title: Neural Machine Translation
summary: A comprehensive treatment of the topic, ranging from introduction to neural networks, computation graphs, description of the currently dominant attentional sequence-to-sequence model, recent refinements, alternative architectures and challenges.
venue: arXiv.org

title: English–Mizo Machine Translation using neural and statistical approaches
summary: Translations predicted by the two approaches have been comparatively and adequately analyzed on a number of grounds to infer their strengths and weaknesses, particularly in low-resource scenarios.
venue: Neural computing & applications (Print)

title: Language-Independent Representor for Neural Machine Translation
summary: A language-independent representor is proposed to replace the encoder and decoder of NMT by using weight sharing, which can not only reduce large portion of network parameters, but also facilitate us to fully explore the language duality by jointly training source-to-target, target- to-source, left- To-right and right-To-left translations within a multi-task learning framework.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Long Zhou,Yuchen Liu,Jiajun Zhang,Chengqing Zong,Guoping Huang

title: Paraphrases as Foreign Languages in Multilingual Neural Machine Translation
summary: This work uses different translations of the whole training data that are consistent in structure as paraphrases at the corpus level to create a multi-paraphrase NMT that trains only on two languages outperforms the multilingual baselines.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Robust Neural Machine Translation with Doubly Adversarial Inputs
summary: This work proposes an approach to improving the robustness of NMT models, which consists of a gradient-based method to craft adversarial examples informed by the translation loss over the clean inputs.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Soft Contextual Data Augmentation for Neural Machine Translation
summary: This work softly augments a randomly chosen word in a sentence by its contextual mixture of multiple related words, replacing the one-hot representation of a word by a distribution (provided by a language model) over the vocabulary.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics
authors: Jinhua Zhu,Fei Gao,Lijun Wu,Yingce Xia,Tao Qin,Wen-gang Zhou,Xueqi Cheng,Tie-Yan Liu

title: Sequence-to-sequence Pre-training with Data Augmentation for Sentence Rewriting
summary: This work separates a seq2seq model with gold training data and augmented data simultaneously, and introduces multiple data augmentation methods to help model pre-training for sentence rewriting.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Yi Zhang,Tao Ge,Furu Wei,Ming Zhou,Xu Sun

title: Data Diversification: An Elegant Strategy For Neural Machine Translation
summary: Data Diversification: a simple strategy to boost neural machine translation (NMT) performance by using the predictions of multiple forward and backward models and then merging them with the original dataset on which the final NMT model is trained is introduced.
venue: arXiv.org
authors: Xuan-Phi Nguyen,Shafiq R. Joty,Wu Kui,A. Aw

title: Transfer learning: bridging the gap between deep learning and domain-specific text mining
summary: This research presents a novel and scalable approach called “Smartphone Mining for Transcript Mining”, which combines smartphone apps and data mining to solve the challenge of illiteracy in the rapidly changing environment.

title: The LMU Munich System for the WMT20 Very Low Resource Supervised MT Task
summary: The best translation system between German and Sorbian is based on transfer learning from a Czech-German system and scores 12 to 13 BLEU higher than a baseline system built using the available parallel data only.
venue: Conference on Machine Translation
authors: Jindřich Libovický,Viktor Hangya,Helmut Schmid,Alexander M. Fraser

title: NRC Systems for Low Resource German-Upper Sorbian Machine Translation 2020: Transfer Learning with Lexical Modifications
summary: The National Research Council of Canada (NRC) neural machine translation systems for the German-Upper Sorbian supervised track of the 2020 shared task on Unsupervised MT and Very Low Resource Supervised MT are described.
venue: Conference on Machine Translation
authors: Rebecca Knowles,Samuel Larkin,Darlene A. Stewart,Patrick Littell

title: SWITCHING-ALIGNED-WORDS DATA AUGMENTATION
summary: This paper randomly replaces words or mixup with their aligned alternatives in another language when training neural machine translation models by using only the original training data without extra data, which significantly outperforms the baseline models.

title: Learning from Small Data Through Sampling an Implicit Conditional Generative Latent Optimization Model
summary: A new model based on conditional Generative Latent Optimization (cGLO) is proposed, which learns to synthesize completely new samples for every class just by interpolating between samples in the latent space.
venue: arXiv.org

title: Paraphrase Augmented Task-Oriented Dialog Generation
summary: A paraphrase augmented response generation (PARG) framework that jointly trains a paraphrase model and a response generation model to improve the dialog generation performance and design a method to automatically construct paraphrase training data set based on dialog state and dialog act labels.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Benchmarking Neural and Statistical Machine Translation on Low-Resource African Languages
summary: This study benchmarked state of the art statistical and neural machine translation systems on two African languages which do not have large amounts of resources: Somali and Swahili, and finds that NMT can significantly improve in performance with the use of these additional data.
venue: International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation

title: Multilingual Neural Machine Translation involving Indian Languages
summary: A data augmentation technique is proposed that further improves this model profoundly and helps achieve a jump of more than 15 points in BLEU score from the multilingual NMT model.
venue: WILDRE

title: Parallel Data Augmentation for Formality Style Transfer
summary: Experiments demonstrate that the augmented parallel data largely helps improve formality style transfer when it is used to pre-train the model, leading to the state-of-the-art results in the GYAFC benchmark dataset.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Neural machine translation of low-resource languages using SMT phrase pair injection
summary: This paper proposes an effective approach to improve an NMT system in low-resource scenario without using any additional data, based on the gated recurrent unit (GRU) and transformer networks, and finds that the proposed method outperforms SMT—which is known to work better than the neural models in high-resource scenarios—for some translation directions.
venue: Natural Language Engineering
authors: Sukanta Sen,Mohammed Hasanuzzaman,Asif Ekbal,P. Bhattacharyya,Andy Way

title: AdvAug: Robust Adversarial Augmentation for Neural Machine Translation
summary: The main idea is to minimize the vicinal risk over virtual sentences sampled from two vicinity distributions, in which the crucial one is a novel vicinity distribution for adversarial sentences that describes a smooth interpolated embedding space centered around observed training sentence pairs.
venue: Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics

title: Simple is Better! Lightweight Data Augmentation for Low Resource Slot Filling and Intent Classification
summary: It is shown that lightweight augmentation, a set of augmentation methods involving word span and sentence level operations, alleviates data scarcity problems and achieves competitive performance with respect to more complex, state-of-the-art, augmentation approaches.
venue: Pacific Asia Conference on Language, Information and Computation

title: SSMBA: Self-Supervised Manifold Based Data Augmentation for Improving Out-of-Domain Robustness
summary: This work introduces SSMBA, a data augmentation method for generating synthetic training examples by using a pair of corruption and reconstruction functions to move randomly on a data manifold, and investigates the use of SSM BA in the natural language domain, leveraging the manifold assumption to reconstruct corrupted text with masked language models.
venue: Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing
